message.content:
<<<api>>>: StringTokenizer.nextToken
<<<code>>>: 
public class WordCount {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        String q = "foo bar foo";
        StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(q);
        Map<String, Integer> terms = new HashMap<String, Integer>();
        while (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
            String term = st.nextToken();
            if (terms.containsKey(term)) {
                terms.put(term, terms.get(term) + 1);
            } else {
                terms.put(term, 1);
            }
        }
        for (Map.Entry<String, Integer> entry : terms.entrySet()) {
            System.out.println(entry.getKey() + ": " + entry.getValue());
        }
    }
}
<<<explanation>>>: This code uses the StringTokenizer class to split the input string into tokens (words), using whitespace as the default delimiter. It then uses a HashMap to count the occurrences of each word. The HashMap's keys are the words, and the values are the counts. If a word is already in the map, it increments the count; otherwise, it adds the word to the map with a count of 1. Finally, it prints out each word and its count.
